title: Context-sensitive neocortical neurons transform the effectiveness and efficiency of neural information processing. (arXiv:2207.07338v6 [cs.NE] UPDATED)
abstract: Deep learning (DL) has big-data processing capabilities that are as good, or even better, than those of humans in many real-world domains, but at the cost of high energy requirements that may be unsustainable in some applications and of errors, that, though infrequent, can be large. We hypothesise that a fundamental weakness of DL lies in its intrinsic dependence on integrate-and-fire point neurons that maximise information transmission irrespective of whether it is relevant in the current context or not. This leads to unnecessary neural firing and to the feedforward transmission of conflicting messages, which makes learning difficult and processing energy inefficient.
